climbs.name: Maverick
climbs.fa: Sykes, rope solo 1995, same day as Lonesome

content.description: Starts like a sport climb, taking on the overhung scoop on the right side of the Tsunami Wall.  Killer crimps, strange grabs, and the right beta take you past three bolts over the lip onto the main face, where a bunch of tenuous 9+ face climbing awaits.  Flow through tricky gear and balancey moves up and slightly left to the two-bolt anchor.   A bit of a sandbag!
content.protection: A few bolts, then some trad gear.  You'll need small finicky stuff.
content.location: The right side of Tsunami Wall has a two-bolt safety anchor on a cool ledge.  Right underneath a steep scoop where two bolt lines lead up and over the lip.  Maverick is the one on the right.

content.description:
"After all this kind of fanfare, and even more, I came to a point where I needed solitude and just stop the machine of "thinking" and "enjoying" what they call "living", I just wanted to lie in the grass and look at the clouds"  -- Jack Kerouac

 A gorgeous climb in a very special locale.  The plumb line right up the middle of Tsunami Wall, offering classic movement on amazing stone.  Navigate the subtle crack system over the crest of the wave, and bullet-hard incuts up and across the steep face to a two-bolt anchor.  Passive pro works well, maybe a couple of cams.  A few bolts help you along the way, but really it's just you and your thoughts up there.  Find your silence!
content.location: Start at the bottom anchor near your packs.  Pass the single bolt on the first face, and take on the roof straight ahead over a weakness.  Head straight up, trending a little right.  Find the anchor nestled on a cozy ledge beneath the firs.

content.description: This route mounts the crest of the Tsumani Wall on the left side, joining a nice crack that leads left past a sappy pine tree to the base of a separate buttress. This new face is followed all the way to the top which is much higher than you would think.  It's a very nice long moderate climb, with great position, and lots of superb moves on killer rock.  The gear can feel a bit tricky at some key moments.  Getting to the crack is a little hairball for the grade!
content.protection: A single rack would suffice for some leaders, but others may want a few extra pieces, especially small stuff. If you have tricams, go ahead and bring 'em.
content.location: Straight up from the chain-anchor at the base of the cliff.   Find a "triangular" cleft at the lip of the roof and note the leftward-trending crack.

content.description:
Not for the feint of heart is both the approach and the base belay for Tsunami Wall !  

  Home to about 10 routes 5.7 to 5.11a, the base belay is on a ledge with a 80 foot drop off.  Fall off this and you'll take the "express train" back to the "T-intersection" at the base of the Bubba Buttress !
